Award.AwardTitle: Excitation and Ionization in Atomic Collision Processes -- General Theory and Accurate Numerical Calculations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project studies the interaction of light (mostly lasers) and charged particles (mostly electrons) with atoms, ions, and small molecules. The results are of importance for the understanding of the fundamental collision dynamics, and they also fulfill the urgent practical need for accurate atomic data to model the physics of stars, plasmas, lasers, and planetary atmospheres. The short-pulse intense-laser part of the project deals with accurate solutions of the time-dependent Schroedinger equation on a numerical space-time grid. With the rapid advances currently seen in computational resources, such studies for realistic rather than idealized model systems have only become possible in recent years. This work is important for further developments in imaging and ultimately controlling of submicroscopic reactions, which is expected to have broad impact by reaching out from physics to chemistry and ultimately biology. Many experimental efforts worldwide are supported through the present project, which will also train a post-doctoral associate and a number of research students in the basic understanding of the problem and the use of highly sophisticated numerical techniques.

Most of the numerical calculations will be based upon the non-perturbative R-matrix (close-coupling) method, as well as direct solutions of the time-dependent Schroedinger equation using various grid-based approaches and basis-function expansions. For single and double ionization of complex atoms by intense atto/femto-second laser pulses, the methods will be combined in such a way that individual parts of the "big problem" can be treated in highly efficient and optimized ways. This strategy will be extended to the treatment of double ionization involving inner shells as well as diatomic molecules. Of particular interest will be the highly challenging, but ultimately necessary simultaneous treatment of the nuclear and electronic motion. There are major difficulties associated with both the formulation of the problem and the subsequent numerical treatment. Much emphasis will be placed on the testing of numerical methods and the visualization of the results, both of which are ideal for student involvement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, benchmark theoretical and numerical studies of collisions of photons, electrons, and other charged particles with atoms and ions were performed. A systematic analysis of the many individual experiments on elastic and inelastic processes, including excitation, direct ionization, auto-ionization, excitation–ionization, and double-ionization for a wide variety of targets in both ground and excited initial states were performed through a combination of a general theoretical description and the development and subsequent application of highly sophisticated numerical methods.

The project resulted in approximately 50 peer-reviewed publications, 4 review articles, the second edition of a book, and a number of invitations for the P.I. as well as the post-doctoral researcher, Dr. Nicolas Douguet, at international conferences, including a plenary talk at the most recent International Conference on Photonic, Electronic, and Atomic Collisions (ICPEAC 2019, held in Deauville, France, in July of 2019).  The P.I. also won the prestigious Will Allis Prize of the America Physical Society in 2016.  Some of those results, which often required work over many years, were also made possible through previous grants in the Atomic Theory program of the NSF, as well as the Computational Physics program through the project # PHY-1520970.

In addition to the scientific outcomes of the project, which support basic research in many laboratories in the United States and around the world, the project resulted in significant development of human resources. A post-doctoral researcher (Dr. Nicolas Douguet) was employed on this grant for two years. He just accepted tenure-track position at Kennesaw State University.  Five undergraduate students (Lorien MacEnulty, Thomas Pauly, Noah Smith, Henry Parker, David Atri-Schuller) worked on REU projects. These students were educated on both the physics of strong-field laser-atom and laser-molecule interactions as well as high-performance computing. A former student (Joel Venzke) is doing very well at the University of Colorado at Boulder (group of Prof. A. Becker).
